questions.text: All of the following cause traumatic asphyxia, except
questions.solution:
Traumatic asphyxia, or Perthes's syndrome, is a medical emergency caused by an intense compression of the thoracic cage, causing back-flow of blood from the right side of the heart into the veins of the neck and the brain.

  • This may occur during road traffic collisions or following collapse of structures such as mine tunnels, or buildings in earthquakes.
  • Pressure on the chest that restricts movement may also occur if the individual simply gets into, or is placed into, a position in which the free movement of the chest is restricted. This positional asphyxia occurs most commonly in individuals that are rendered immobile through alcohol or drugs and may be seen following restraint in custodial settings.
  • It may also be seen in the healthy, for example, attempting to climb through a small window to gain access to a property.

questions.text: A 26 year old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of dimunition of vision which recovered on treatment with steroids. She also has history of transverse myelitis. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of this patient is Neuromyelitis Optica.

It is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis.

Attacks of Optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments.

Drugs used in acute attacks: high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange.

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses: Mycophenolate Mofetil, Rituximab, Glucocorticoids + Azathioprine.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes to the surgery out-patient clinic with the following appearance of his lower limb.  Which of the following forms a surface landmark for the structure shown?

choices.text: On the lateral border of the tibia at the junction of upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd
Just medial to the tendo-calcaneus above the medial malleolus
Dorsum of the foot, at the medial end of the dorsal venous arch
At the centre of the popliteal fossa draining into the popliteal vein

questions.solution:
The image shows varicosities of the great saphenous vein. The dorsum of the foot, at the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, forms the surface marking.

The surface marking for it is marked by joining the following points from foot to thigh:

  1. On the dorsum of the foot, at the medial end of the dorsal venous arch.
  2. On the anterior surface of the medial malleolus.
  3. On the medial border of the tibia at the junction of the upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd of the leg.
  4. At the adductor tubercle.
  5. Just below the centre of the saphenous opening.

The small saphenous vein is marked by:

  1. On the dorsum of the foot, at the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch.
  2. Behind the lateral malleolus. 
  3. Just lateral to the tendocalcaneous above the lateral malleolus.
  4. At the centre of the popliteal fossa draining into the popliteal vein(Option D).

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male complains of burning sensation in both the legs and episodes of excruciating pain, tingling and a sensation he describes as "pins and needles". Which of the following is a first-line drug used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from painful diabetic neuropathy in the scenario given above. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Painful diabetic neuropathy manifests as burning, excruciating, stabbing or intractable type of pain or presents with tingling or numbness. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to primarily metabolic and vascular factors.

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First-line:

  • Lidoderm 5% patch
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Duloxetine

Second line:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Venlafaxine
  • Tramadol

Third line:

  • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: As a psychiatrist, you advise one of your patients suffering from the phobic disorder to undergo systematic desensitization therapy as a part of behavioral therapy. Systematic desensitization includes all the following steps except ______
questions.solution:
Flooding is not a part of systematic desensitization. Flooding involves repeated and prolonged exposure to fear cues of high intensity without relaxation

Systematic desensitization consists of three steps:

  • Relaxation training: patients attain a state of complete relaxation and are then exposed to the stimulus that elicits the anxiety response. The negative reaction of anxiety is inhibited by the relaxed state, a process called reciprocal inhibition.
  • Hierarchy construction: Patients and therapists prepare a graded list (or hierarchy) fear-provoking scenes in the order of increasing anxiety.
  • Desensitization of the stimulus: Patients proceed systematically through the list from the least to the most anxiety-provoking scene while in a deeply relaxed state.

questions.text: As an anesthesia consultant, you're planning to insert a central venous line for a patient requiring inotropes and parenteral nutrition. Which of the following veins will you choose so as to have reduced long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given options subclavian is the best vein for long-term cannulation with the least long-term side effects.

It is however associated with a maximum risk of pneumothorax. Moreover, in case of bleeding diathesis or patient on anticoagulants, subclavian is less preferred due to inability to provide direct pressure over the vein to stop bleeding.

Other options:

The internal jugular vein on the right side is better than the left side. Left-sided insertion has an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax. If subclavian can't be cannulated, this should be preferred.

The external jugular vein is less preferred because it enters at acute angle into chest veins, hence there is decreased chances of easy access.

Femoral veins are less preferred for long term usage because they are associated with frequent line-related sepsis.

questions.text: A person with a gunshot wound of size 3 cm presents with a comminuted fracture of the tibia. On examination, the distal pulse could not be felt. Which grade does this belong to according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
The above-described wound belongs to grade IIIC according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification.

Gustilo and Anderson's classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures. An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

Related Pearl: Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fracture

        II Wound >1cm in length but without any soft tissue damage and skin flap or avulsion
        III Wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, comminution, contamination or segmental fractures 
        IIIA Adequate Periosteal coverage is there
        IIIB Significant Periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone covering procedures like skin flap or grafting.
        IIIC Open fracture with vascular injury that requires vascular repair

Types and method of fixation:

Grade  I                                Technique that is suitable for closed fracture management i.e, debridement and internal fixation by intramedullary nail and plate  
Grade II,IIIA

questions.text: Berkesonian bias is a type of  _______
questions.solution:
Berkesonian bias is a type of selection bias.

It is due to the different rates of hospital admission of people with different diseases, termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida in her third trimester is brought to the ER in an altered state of consciousness. Lab tests reveal elevated AST, ALT, and bilirubin, while a liver biopsy shows microvesicular fatty infiltration. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The mother has acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), which is associated with long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase (3-LCHAD) deficiency. This enzyme is involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

Free fatty acids normally increase in pregnancy, particularly during late gestation to fuel fetoplacental growth and development. In fetuses homozygous for LCHAD deficiency, the fetoplacental unit is unable to undertake fatty acid metabolism adequately. This contributes to the accumulation of long-chain metabolites in maternal blood and hepatocytes, resulting in toxic effects.

Acute fatty liver is a rare, potentially fatal complication that occurs late in pregnancy, most commonly in the third trimester or early postpartum period. It is associated with:

  • Male fetus
  • First pregnancy
  • Maternal obesity.

AFLP leads to acute hemolysis and thrombocytopenia. Other features include:

  • Persistent nausea and vomiting
  • Progressive jaundice
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Edema.

Investigations

  • Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised.
  • Hemolysis with coagulopathy
    • Decreased platelets and fibrinogen
    • Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time
  • Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

Management

  • Intensive supportive measures
  • C-section to hasten delivery
  • Hepatic dysfunction resolves postpartum.

questions.text: Identify the culture medium shown in the given image_________
questions.solution:
Loeffler's serum slope is an Enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Advantage of Loeffler's serum slope

  • Rapid growth(6-8 hrs)
  • Best medium for metachromatic granules production

Disadvantage: As it is not a selective medium, if incubated beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals also.

Other options:

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. Thayer Martin Medium selectively favors the growth of Neisseria by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with Vancomycin, gram-negative organisms (except Neisseria) with Trimethoprim and Colistin, and fungi with Nystatin

Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar.

Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the image below. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture.The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium bovis forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on LJ media that break-up easily when touched. 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies with a wrinkled surface, tenacious, difficult to emulsify, creamy white and buff-colored. (Rough, tough, buff). 

 Middle Brook’s media:

  • Liquid Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The flow cytometry of cells is as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given pattern is suggestive of B-CLL.

Interpreting flow cytometry graph:

See the markers on X-axis and Y-axis. Divide the graph into 4 quadrants.

1)In the first graph, X-axis shows CD5 and Y-axis shows CD19. The particular cell population in question is positive for CD19 and CD5.

2)In the second graph, it is shown the cells are negative for CD10 and positive for CD19.

3)The third graph shows CD 23 is positive. CD20 is dimly expressed.

4)FMC-7 is negative. CD20 is dimly expressed.

 

It is understood from the cytometry analysis that the cells are positive for CD5, CD19, CD23, CD20.  All these suggest the diagnosis of B-CLL.

 

 

Other options:

  • Mantle cell lymphoma can be diagnosed by its characteristic immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, CD22+, CD23(-), CD 5+.
  • DLBCL and Follicular lymphoma are positive for CD10.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. What is the sign and the significance of the sign that is demonstrated in this image?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance

Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.

X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.

Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.

Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.

The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.

USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.

USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of multiple discharging sinuses for the past 6 months as shown in the image below. Parents say that they initially started as bluish swellings. Later, they ulcerated to form these lesions. Mantoux test was done and it showed an induration measuring 30 mm at 72 hours. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows scrofuloderma which is cutaneous tuberculosis. Multiple swellings with ulcers and sinuses can be seen in this image.

Scrofuloderma results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from an underlying contiguous tuberculous focus. This is usually a lymph gland, an infected bone or joint, lacrimal gland or duct, breast, or testes. It commonly occurs in children. It begins as bluish-red subcutaneous swellings which ulcerate to form discharging sinuses.

Other options

Option A- Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It presents as slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion gradually extend in some areas and heal with scarring in others. In India, the buttocks, and trunk more frequently involved. Apple jelly nodules are demonstrated on diascopy.

Below image- Lupus vulgaris

Option C- Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It occurs due to hypersensitivity to the active tubercular infection. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. The lesions are usually skin coloured and are often perifollicular. The papule may have an adherent crust or small pustule.

Below image- Lichen scrofulosorum

Other types of tuberculids are

1. Papulonecrotic tuberculids consist of symmetrical, hard, dusky red papules. These crust or ulcerate, leaving a pigmented and atrophic scar.

Below image- Papulonecrotic tuberculid

2. Erythema induratum of Bazin- It is the most commonly reported tuberculid. They present with crops of small, tender, and painful erythematous or dusky nodules or plaques on the calves which may ulcerate. Most patients will have a positive tuberculin test and respond well to antituberculous therapy.

Below image- Erythema induratum of Bazin

Option D-Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. Lesions appear at the site of inoculation. They appear as verrucous plaque which extends with a serpiginous outline with finger‐like projections. The center of the lesion may have a white atrophic scar.

Below image- Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis
